items.title: Building a job results in "ValueError: Not a Queue URL", but job gets built anyway
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### Jenkinsapi 0.3.11

##### Jenkins 2.190.2

##### SUMMARY
When building a job with Jenkins.build_job(), the queue URL validity check always fails, because the port is included in my Jenkins URL. The job is anyway built.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
The job is built and the script finishes cleanly.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
The job is built, but the script end with "ValueError: Not a Queue URL"

##### USEFUL INFORMATION

In my case, the validity checker in Job.invoke fails, because it tries to check that redirect_url:
`http://<JENKINS_SERVER>/queue/item/893/`
starts with
`http://<JENKINS_SERVER>:8080/queue/item`

Removing the port from the Jenkins server address fixes the issue, but I guess this is not the desired behaviour.

I am not sure how to check for the URL validity in all cases, otherwise I would try to submit a PR...

Stack trace:
```[...]
  File ".../.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/jenkinsapi/job.py", line 236, in invoke
    raise ValueError("Not a Queue URL: %s" % redirect_url)
ValueError: Not a Queue URL: http://<JENKINS_SERVER>/queue/item/893/
```

items.title: Support for user specified delay (quiet period) when starting a job
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### Jenkinsapi 0.3.10

##### Jenkins Latest LTS

##### SUMMARY
jenkinsapi does not support passing delay parameter (quiet period) when starting job

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
jenkinsapi allows user to define quiet period for job's invoke method

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
jenkinsapi does not allow user to define quiet period for job's invoke method. This causes a notable delay (default 5secs) for user that is invoking the task

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
delay parameter can be passed to jenkins in uri using format: delay=XXsec . e.g. delay=0sec

items.title: job.get_scm_url() does not work on multibranch pipelines
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - Feature Idea

##### Jenkinsapi 0.3.10

##### Jenkins 2.190

##### SUMMARY
job.get_scm_url() does not work on multibranch pipelines

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
to return the scm (git) url

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
error: AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'get'

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
I want to propose a pull-request, but would like some input on that.
I could parse the config-tree to get the scm-url (I'll need to concatenate different fields but that will be ok), I can get the branch name (from the job url actually). I'll hav eto rewrite the code though to differentiate from the normal `git` scm type.

 For the moment there are already 4 scm types:

 - svn
 - git
 - hg
 - null

I see two possible implementations:

 - add a new "bitbucket" or "multibranch" scm type, but in reality it is also `git`
 - rewrite the internal code so that I can always yield `git` as the scm_type, but internally I'll have to make the difference between this multibranch and original git case.

items.title: job.invoke() cannot handle baseurl including standard port 443 / 80
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report


##### Jenkinsapi 0.39.0

##### Jenkins 2.164.3

##### SUMMARY
When adding a standard port to the baseurl for job invocations, the verification within the invoke function does not work, because in the HTTP response location the standard port is abandoned.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
Job invokation happens succesfully.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Resolution of the jenkins queue is not successfull.

##### USEFUL INFORMATION

Example Code:
```
from jenkinsapi.jenkins import Jenkins
from jenkinsapi.job import Job
from jenkinsapi.utils.crumb_requester import CrumbRequester

def trigger_jenkins_job(jenkins_obj, job_url, job_name, build_parameters):
    job = Job(url=job_url, name=job_name, jenkins_obj=jenkins_obj)
    qi = job.invoke(block=True, build_params=build_parameters,cause="Triggered externally via script")
    build = qi.get_build()
    return build

def get_server_instance(jenkins_url, user, password):
    crumb_requester = CrumbRequester(baseurl=jenkins_url, username=user, password=password, ssl_verify=False)
    server = Jenkins(jenkins_url, username=user, password=password, requester=crumb_requester, ssl_verify=False, lazy=True)
    return server

def test_invoke_job():
    jenkins_url = "https://jenkins-company.com:443"
    user = "myuser"
    password = "mypassword"
    jenkins_obj = get_server_instance(jenkins_url, user=user, password=password)

    build_parameters = {"SRC_PATH":"/tmp/test1",
                        "DEST_DIR":"/tmp/test2"}

    trigger_jenkins_job(jenkins_obj=jenkins_obj,
                        job_url=jenkins_url + "/job/copy_file/",
                        job_name="copy_file",
                        build_parameters=build_parameters)
```

items.title: QueueItem.get_build retrieves incorrect build

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Will accept pull request as top priority

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues not active for more than 30 days

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
Bug Report

##### Jenkinsapi 0.3.8

##### Jenkins 2.150.3

##### SUMMARY
We use jenkinsapi to invoke a build, we get the QueueItem, wait for it to start, get the build and wait for the build to complete. However with one job, the builds were randomly reported as failing even though jenkins showed them succeeding. Diving into this show that the build doesn't in anyway match the QueueItem. I.e. QueueItem was returning a build for another job that had already completed.

###### PROBLEM
`QueueItem.get_build` effectively returns `self.jenkins[self._data['task']['name']][self._data['executable']['number']]`. But in the case you make use of Jenkins folders and you have a job with the same task name in different folders you don't necessarily get the correct one.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### Jenkinsapi VERSION
0.3.8

##### Jenkins VERSION
CloudBees Jenkins Enterprise 2.107.36.0.2-fixed

##### SUMMARY
Attempt to launch a build against a CloudBees team space URL failed with an exception from jenkinsapi.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
I successfully used jenkinsapi to create a remote project (not shown), which resulted in a POST to the following URL: https://server.domain.com/jenkins/job/my_team/createItem

I expected the following snippet to work:

```
from jenkinsapi.jenkins import Jenkins
from jenkinsapi.utils.crumb_requester import CrumbRequester
base_url = "https://server.domain.com/jenkins/job/my_team"
username = "me"
password = "my_token"
crumb = CrumbRequester(baseurl=base_url, username=username, password=password)
jenkins = Jenkins(base_url, username=username, password=password)
job = jenkins['my_project']
job.invoke()
```

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
The call to job.invoke threw the following exception:

```
  File "/nobackup/mdear/jenkins-engine/lib/python3.5/site-packages/jenkinsapi/job.py", line 215, in invoke
    raise ValueError("Not a Queue URL: %s" % redirect_url)
ValueError: Not a Queue URL: https://engci-jenkins-sjc2.cisco.com/jenkins/queue/item/449093/

items.title: A Build that has been polled while is_running will not transition to is_good

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues not active for more than 30 days

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### Jenkinsapi VERSION
`0.3.8`

##### Jenkins VERSION
`2.150.2`

##### SUMMARY
A single `Build` object (as returned by `Job.get_build(buildid)`) will transition from `is_running` to `not is_running`, but it will not transition from `not is_good` to `is_good` at the same time.

A small repro of this looks like:
```
>>> j = get_jenkins_job('my-job')
>>> b = j.get_build(22)
>>> import time
>>> while True:
...   time.sleep(1.0)
...   print(b.is_running(), b.is_good())
...
(True, False)
(True, False)
(True, False)
(False, False)
(False, False)
(False, False)
(False, False)
(False, False)
^CTraceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 2, in <module>
KeyboardInterrupt
>>> b = j.get_build(23)
>>> print(b.is_running(), b.is_good())
(False, True)
```
In short: the job is initially running, but completes at some point. But when it completes, `is_good` does not begin to return the final result for the build. If you recreate the `Build` object, you see the final result for the build.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
I would expect that when `not is_running`, the final result/status of the job would be visible via `is_good`.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
See above.

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### Jenkinsapi VERSION
0.3.7

##### Jenkins VERSION
2.121.3

##### SUMMARY

When using a username & Token combo to invoke jobs and query certain statuses I get back errors

* Getting back 403 Client error after querying for status
* Getting back ValueError after invoking a build

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
JOB queue / status

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 403 Client Error: Forbidden for url:

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
```
from jenkinsapi import jenkins

j = jenkins.Jenkins('https://<username>:<token>@<jenkinsurl>')
jb = j.get_job('Build/MyJOB/build/xxx')

jb.invoke()

jb.is_queued_or_running()

```

`jb.is_queued()` works fine
`jb.is_running()` fails as above


What is interesting is that when I create the jenkins instance i use: `'https://<username>:<token>@<jenkinsurl>'` but the url that is failing in the response is `'https://<jenkinsurl>'`

Digging deeper the issue seems to lie in `https://github.com/pycontribs/jenkinsapi/blob/0.3.7/jenkinsapi/job.py` in the `get_build_dict(self)` method. 
This method is returning the dict containing `{'job#': 'https://<jenkinsurl>/job/Build/job/MYJOB/job/build%2Fxxx/16/' }` which is missing the credentials. 


Proof of Fix:
```
from jenkinsapi import jenkins

j = jenkins.Jenkins('https://<username>:<token>@<jenkinsurl>')
jb = j.get_job('Build/MyJOB/build/xxx')

# Falsify the return so it returns a 'valid' url
jb.__dict__["get_build_dict"] = (lambda: dict( [(16, 'https://<username>:<token>@<jenkinsurl>/job/Build/job/MYJOB/job/build%2Fxxx/16/' )] ))

items.title: Provide "public" getter-methods
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - How to...
- Feature request

##### Jenkinsapi 0.3.6

##### Jenkins 1.658

##### SUMMARY
<!--- Explain the problem briefly -->
Hey!

**Disclaimer: I'm far from being a Python expert, so chances are I didn't get something important.**
Here's what I wanna do: I wanna select a view, iterate through all the jobs therein and get the console output of each job's last build for later parsing purposes. 
In views.py there is a method that does just what I need:
```
 def __getitem__(self, view_name):
```
The double-leading-underscores tell me that this method is "private", and from what I know it would be very bad practice to get a view via this method, for example it could be gone in a future version and my code wouldn't work anymore...
So right now, in order to avoid using this "private" function, I came up with a quite akward solution:
projectSelection contains a list of all views
```
        for s in projectSelection:
            for viewKey, view in jenkins.views.iteritems():
                if viewKey == s:
                    for jobKey, job in view.iteritems():
                        # Further processing...
                        pass 

                else:
                    continue
```
Thanks for this nice API!

Best regards, Klaus

items.title: Artifact.save() fails with ArtifactBroken exception if different artifacts on different builds have the same content

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues not active for more than 30 days

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report
##### Jenkinsapi VERSION
0.3.6
##### Jenkins VERSION
2.121.3
##### SUMMARY
My Jenkins job generates multiple artifacts (XML-formatted test results in particular) and those don't defer much either across builds (job runs) or between each other. Therefore, it may easily happen that e.g. artifact_1 from build_1 has the same content (and therefore the same MD5 / fingerprint) as artifact_2 from build_2. To make the problem more obvious and easier to t-shoot, you may optionally turn on "Fingerprint all archived artifacts" option for the "Archive the artifacts" post-build action. In that case, Jenkins will you a table view of all the artifacts in each build and links between those that have the same content. In my example, Jenkins will show artifact_1 (from build_1) linked with artifact_2 (from build_2) as its "Original owner".
When I'm using JenkinsAPI from Python and call Artifact.save() method for artifact_2 on build_2, I'm getting ArtifactBroken exception. Further debugging of Artifact.save() method shows that exception came from Artifact._verify_download() call, since Fingerprint.validate_for_build() returned False. And the reason for that was failing the (self._data["fileName"] != filename) check on line 80 since artifact_1 and artifact_2 obviously have different name. Good thing is that exception is thrown after the content is downloaded and save on the local file system, so I can catch and just ignore ArtifactBroken exception, but... 

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
It would be best if no exception would be thrown at all in this case, as the file was downloaded correctly, its MD5 hash matches the one on Jenkins and the file is valid (i.e. it's not a broken artifact). It would also be acceptable if I'd get a different exception type that would be specific to this case, so I could decide what to do.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
As explained in the description part, I'm getting a misleading ArtifactBroken just because the artifact content matches with some other artifact content from the past build.

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
All the details provided in the description, but please feel free to reach out for details.

<!--- Paste example code and full stacktrace below -->
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:/my_example.py", line 20, in example_method
    artifact.save_to_dir(dest)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jenkinsapi\artifact.py", line 130, in save_to_dir
    return self.save(outputfilepath, strict_validation)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jenkinsapi\artifact.py", line 63, in save
    self._verify_download(filepath, strict_validation)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\jenkinsapi\artifact.py", line 104, in _verify_download
    % (local_md5, baseurl)
ArtifactBroken: Artifact <artifact_md5> seems to be broken, check <my_jenkins_url>

items.title: comparison between jenkinsapi and python-jenkins libraries

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues not active for more than 30 days

items.body:
We need to make a comparison of multiple jenkins libraries and guide users about which one they should use or avoid. If possible we should also aim to consolidate these libraries, if possible, so efforts will no longer be divergent. It is much better to have one library that is well mantained than many less maintained ones.

* https://pypi.org/project/python-jenkins/ - under OpenStack umbrella, well maintained, @ssbarnea is one of the maintainers
* https://pypi.org/project/jenkinsapi/ - less maintained, also @lechat being one active maintainer
* https://pypi.org/project/jenkins/ - abandonware - we may be able to obtain the pypi namespace in the future if we want, see https://github.com/lgastako/jenkins/issues/3

items.title: How actively maintained is this project?

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Will accept pull request as top priority

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Maintenance Activity

##### SUMMARY

First off, I really enjoy this projects goals and concept. So thanks for all the work! 

Given it has a large following and a number of issues/features that could use addressing, I feel like this project could use some TLC. Mainly, improving **test coverage** (so that way we can make large strides in closing out some of the issues quickly), improving/updating the **documentation**, making it easier to clone and **develop with minimal setup effort**, and closing some of the **outstanding PRs**. 

I would like to make some decent PRs, but I want to be assured that they will be reviewed and eventually merged (if applicable) at some point.  Is there anyone here that could help (or can I help in some way) in reviewing and closing some the PR's? 

Pardon me if this is not the place to discuss this, but I have tried contacting the maintainers through email, Google Groups, the Gitter channel and Github. 

Thanks for any clarification!

labels.name: help wanted

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues not active for more than 30 days

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### Jenkinsapi 0.3.6

##### Jenkins 2.89.4

##### SUMMARY
If there are two artifacts with the same filename, but different relative path, the api.get_artifacts() will return just one, instead of both.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
If artifacts shown in Jenkins have the following structure: folder1/filename and folder2/filename I'd expect api.get_artifacts() to return both.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
api.get_artifacts() returns a dictionary with the last artifact, folder2/filename.

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
The build.get_artifacts() creates a dictionary based on filename. I understand that this is useful when there's a flat folder structure. To cover all cases I'd suggest returning a dictionary based on relative path rather than filename.

```
def get_artifact_dict(self):
        return dict(
            (af.relative_path, af) for af in self.get_artifacts()
        )
```

items.title: crumb_requester.py - __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'user'
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### Jenkinsapi VERSION
0.3.6

##### Jenkins VERSION
2.101

##### SUMMARY
I am receiving the following error by running one of the how_to/use_crumbs examples. 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 5, in <module>
  File "/Users/rogerio.c.peixoto/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/jenkinsapi/utils/crumb_requester.py", line 15, in __init__
    super(CrumbRequester, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'user'
```

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
Should be able to print all jobs in specified Jenkins.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
The following error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 5, in <module>
  File "/Users/rogerio.c.peixoto/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/jenkinsapi/utils/crumb_requester.py", line 15, in __init__
    super(CrumbRequester, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs)
TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'user'
```

##### USEFUL INFORMATION

python --version
Python 2.7.10

Crumb example code (test_connection.py) :
```
"""
Example of using CrumbRequester - when CSRF protection is enable in Jenkins
"""
from jenkinsapi.jenkins import Jenkins
from jenkinsapi.utils.crumb_requester import CrumbRequester

jenkins = Jenkins('https://jenkins.xxxxxxx.net', user='rogerio.c.peixoto', password='xxxxxx', requester=CrumbRequester('https://jenkins.xxxxxx.net', user='rogerio.c.peixoto', password='xxxxx'))

for job_name in jenkins.jobs:
  print job_name
```

items.title: canonicalize xml for update_config
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report (slight inconvenience)

##### Jenkinsapi==0.3.6

##### Jenkins 2.96 and older

##### SUMMARY
XML config posted to jenkins via `server.update_config(cfg)` is never canonicalized, but jenkins always canonicalizes their own XML when saving on the web interface.

This leads to the `jobConfigHistory` plugin (or API diffs) to always show changes with local saves even when there's no functional difference in the XML.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
- `server.update_config(some_cfg)`
- goto web interface, press configure on corr. job, save (without actually changing anything)
- check that jobConfigHistory has no new diffs for this job.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Job config history shows swathes of diffs like:

```diff
+<defaultValue></defaultValue>
-<defaultValue/>
```

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
I've tried passing my ETree grenerated xml through `xmllint --c14n` first, but when posting the result of that to `update_config`, my canonicalization is always undone by something inside jenkinsapi.

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### SUMMARY
Add a function that executes groovy scripts on the jenkins script console.

I am currently writing on a python script that configures my jenkins instance after installation.
In the process I have to execute groovy scripts via commands like

````sh
curl --user 'Knitschi:1234password' -H "Jenkins-Crumb:fa04d81b133e" --data-urlencode "script=My lengthy script" localhost:8080/scriptText
````

It would be awesome if i could write
````python
server = Jenkins(...)
script = "My lengthy script"
server.run_script(script)
````

items.title: Hang observed when server offline
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - Bug Report


##### Jenkinsapi VERSION
0.3.4

##### Jenkins VERSION
2.72

##### SUMMARY
Infinite timeout causes a hang when server is not up.

After suspending the server, I created my Jenkins object and then performed a truth test against it, hoping to compare "jenkins.version" against "0.0" to check for server up/down.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
I expected a reasonably quick response (ie. within 1 second) if the server was down

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
The call hang, further debugging showed that the timeout was set to default None.

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
On my server, 
kill -STOP <jenkins_pid>
from jenkinsapi.jenkins import Jenkins
jenkins = Jenkins("http://my_server.domain.com:8080", username="me", password="auth_token")
True if jenkins else False

The above works after executing on my server
kill -CONT <jenkins_pid>

items.title: Fingerprint validation fails for matrix projects

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Will accept pull request as top priority

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues not active for more than 30 days

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### Jenkinsapi 0.3.4

##### Jenkins 2.60.3 with DynamicAxis plugin

##### SUMMARY
Download artifacts (artifact.save()), fail when using a matrix job (same job is built on different environments). Download in itself work, but fingerprint verification fail (fingerprint.validate_for_build()).

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
Fingerprint validation must success or could be degraded.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Fingerprint validation fail to associate downloaded artifact with the current job. This bug is similar to #537 but for matrix jobs.

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
Job name: MyJob
Subjob name : MyJob/platform=linux

In Fingerprint.py, original.name is checked with 'job.name' and build number. In our case, Job name is the prefix of our subjob.

Options:
- Add a way to check only hash existence and doesn't try check jobs informations
- In artifact.py / verify_download found a way to found//build matrix name.
- ...

Since this Fingerprint validation may fail depending on Jenkins plugins, configurations, ... maybe add an option to check if the downloaded file match with a MD5 know by Jenkins (and with our current build number) but don't try to enforce exact job name ?

Thanks,

items.title: Use with Jenkins Multibranch Pipeline Jobs

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Issues not active for more than 30 days

items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - How to...
Get Job information for jobs configured with Jenkins  Multibranch Pipeline 

##### Jenkinsapi VERSION
latest
##### Jenkins VERSION
2.7.1
##### SUMMARY
Is the support for getting job infos from a multibranch  pipeline plugin added to the jenkinsapi ?
I could find that there was an issue already created for the same :
https://github.com/pycontribs/jenkinsapi/issues/358

And it looks like someone has committed in 
https://github.com/pycontribs/jenkinsapi/pull/538

But, I'm not sure how to get it done with the api. 
NB: Not an expert programmer :)

I have a multibranch pipeline implemented in Jenkins, where there are jobs with same name, recurring in different branchs/folders within the multibranch pipeline.
But the api returns only information from 1st branch.
##### EXPECTED RESULTS
Information for all jobs with same name within different branches implemented in Pipeline

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Information from the 1st occurrence of the job only

Thanks,
Ron

items.title: create job failed when the config is byte type
items.body:
##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - Bug Report


##### Jenkinsapi VERSION
0.3.4

##### Python VERSION
Python 3.5
##### SUMMARY
<!--- Explain the problem briefly -->
when use ``Jobs.create(self, job_name, config)`` method to create a job,  if the config is byte type, it will create job failed.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
<!--- What did you expect to happen when running the steps above? -->
create job success

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
<!--- What actually happened? If possible run with extra verbosity (-vvvv) -->
create job failed

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
<!---
For bugs, show exactly how to reproduce the problem.
For new features, show how the feature would be used.
-->
when use Jobs.create method to create a job, if the config is byte, it will wrap it as a string
```
    def create(self, job_name, config):
        """
        Create a job

        :param str jobname: Name of new job
        :param str config: XML configuration of new job
        :returns Job: new Job object
        """
        if job_name in self:
            return self[job_name]

        if config is None or len(config) == 0:
            raise JenkinsAPIException('Job XML config cannot be empty')

        params = {'name': job_name}
        # the below code is the problem occure
        config = str(config)  # cast unicode in case of Python 2
```
if the config is a byte, the ``config=str(config)`` will make a wrong xml format, 
e.g. 
```
config = b'123'
assert config==b'123'
config = str(config) 
assert config=="b'123'" #   the config will become "b'123'", which changed the config's content 
```

job = jenkins.get_job(str('FolderB/Deploy'))
queue_item = job.invoke(build_params=params)

##### ISSUE TYPE
How to trigger a parameterized jenkins job remotely using python requests passing in a file parameter? 

##### Jenkinsapi VERSION

N/A

##### Jenkins VERSION
2.63

##### SUMMARY
I have a Jenkins job that accepts a file parameter. I want to trigger it remotely using python requests library.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
I was expecting the remote job to be triggered with the contents of file.log saved in ${WORKSPACE}/files/abc.zip

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
This code triggers a build but the file /some/file/path/file.log is not posted to the Jenkins job. 
The contents are not available in ${WORKSPACE}/files/abc.zip

##### USEFUL INFORMATION
I did this

```
url = 'myurl/buildWithParameters'
data = {'Jenkins-Crumb': '8f4d0320c0982763098571789b2b65ec', 'token': 'mytoken'}
filepath='/some/file/path/file.log'
files = {'file': ('files/abc.zip', open(filepath, 'rb')) }
r = requests.post(url, data=data, files=files)
```
